items.title: Starmer set to announce UK recognition of Palestinian state
items.standfirst: A host of countries, including France and Canada, are expected to do the same when world leaders gather at the UN General Assembly next week.
items.content: A host of countries, including France and Canada, are expected to do the same when world leaders gather at the UN General Assembly next week.

items.title: United Kingdom and Portugal to recognise Palestinian state
items.standfirst: Britain and Portugal are set to recognize the State of Palestine on Sunday, ahead of a key week at the UN General Assembly in New York, where around 10 countries may follow suit to pressure Israel over Gaza. UK media report that Prime Minister Keir Starmer will announce the move despite strong Israeli opposition. France 24’s Bénédicte Paviot reports from London.
items.content: Britain and Portugal are set to recognize the State of Palestine on Sunday, ahead of a key week at the UN General Assembly in New York, where around 10 countries may follow suit to pressure Israel over Gaza. UK media report that Prime Minister Keir Starmer will announce the move despite strong Israeli opposition. France 24’s Bénédicte Paviot reports from London.

items.title: Gaza, Palestinian state recognition set to dominate UN General Assembly summit
items.standfirst: Saudi Arabia and France will co-chair meetings at the UN General Assembly summit beginning Monday on a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The French presidency said Friday that 10 countries would formally recognise Palestinian statehood during the summit.
items.content: Saudi Arabia and France will co-chair meetings at the UN General Assembly summit beginning Monday on a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The French presidency said Friday that 10 countries would formally recognise Palestinian statehood during the summit.

items.title: UK set to recognize Palestinian state despite opposition from the US
items.standfirst: The U.K. is expected to recognize a Palestinian state later Sunday despite opposition from the U.S., after judging that Israel has not met conditions it set over the war in Gaza.
items.content: The U.K. is expected to recognize a Palestinian state later Sunday despite opposition from the U.S., after judging that Israel has not met conditions it set over the war in Gaza.(Image credit: Leon Neal)

items.title: Heightened security ahead of UN Assembly as countries move to recognise Palestinian state
items.standfirst: Ahead of the 80th United Nations General Assembly, the United States is taking security precautions in the aftermath of the assassination of far-right activist Charlie Kirk and as several countries are set to recognize the Palestinian state. Jessica Le Masurier, S. Anderson and H. Ibrahim report.
items.content: Ahead of the 80th United Nations General Assembly, the United States is taking security precautions in the aftermath of the assassination of far-right activist Charlie Kirk and as several countries are set to recognize the Palestinian state. Jessica Le Masurier, S. Anderson and H. Ibrahim report.

items.content: Multiple recognitions are expected despite strong pushback from Israel and the US amid intensifying attacks on Gaza.

items.content: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said on Sunday that he hopes new decisions at the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) will speed up efforts toward a two-state solution for Palestine. Speaki...

items.title: Starmer to announce recognition of Palestinian state on Sunday, UK media reports say
items.standfirst: UK Prime Minister is expected to formally recognise a Palestinian state on Sunday, according to UK media reports. Starmer said in July that the move would contribute to a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, something vehemently opposed by the Israeli government.
items.content: UK Prime Minister is expected to formally recognise a Palestinian state on Sunday, according to UK media reports. Starmer said in July that the move would contribute to a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, something vehemently opposed by the Israeli government.

items.title: Live: UK, Portugal to recognise Palestinian state ahead of UN General Assembly gathering
items.standfirst: The UK and Portugal were on Sunday expected to recognise a Palestinian state ahead of the UN General Assembly meeting in New York this week, where the so-called two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will be front and centre. Thousands of Gazans on Saturday continued to flee Gaza City, the focus of the Israeli military’s expanded offensive. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.
items.content: The UK and Portugal were on Sunday expected to recognise a Palestinian state ahead of the UN General Assembly meeting in New York this week, where the so-called two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will be front and centre. Thousands of Gazans on Saturday continued to flee Gaza City, the focus of the Israeli military’s expanded offensive. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

items.title: Why Starmer decided the time was right to recognise a Palestinian state
items.standfirst: The PM had signalled a shift in policy unless Israel took steps including agreeing to a ceasefire in Gaza.
items.content: The PM had signalled a shift in policy unless Israel took steps including agreeing to a ceasefire in Gaza.

items.title: UK set to recognise Palestinian state on Sunday
items.standfirst: Keir Starmer expected to confirm move after concluding the situation has worsened significantly in recent weeksThe UK is expected to recognise a Palestinian state on Sunday after Israel failed to meet the conditions set out by Keir Starmer in July.The prime minister is to make the announcement after concluding the humanitarian situation has deteriorated significantly in the past few weeks. The move comes despite pressure from the US and the families of hostages held by Hamas. Continue reading...
items.content: Keir Starmer expected to confirm move after concluding the situation has worsened significantly in recent weeksThe UK is expected to recognise a Palestinian state on Sunday after Israel failed to meet the conditions set out by Keir Starmer in July.The prime minister is to make the announcement after concluding the humanitarian situation has deteriorated significantly in the past few weeks. The move comes despite pressure from the US and the families of hostages held by Hamas. Continue reading...

items.title: Palestinian minister says UK recognition of state a 'courageous step'
items.standfirst: Britain will be taking "a courageous step at a very difficult time" by officially recognising a Palestinian state, according to the authority's foreign minister, who told Sky News she believes the announcement - expected today - will inspire more nations to follow suit.
items.content: Britain will be taking "a courageous step at a very difficult time" by officially recognising a Palestinian state, according to the authority's foreign minister, who told Sky News she believes the announcement - expected today - will inspire more nations to follow suit.

items.title: Portugal confirms it will recognise Palestinian state
items.standfirst: A host of countries, including France and the UK, are expected to do the same when world leaders gather at the UN General Assembly next week.
items.content: A host of countries, including France and the UK, are expected to do the same when world leaders gather at the UN General Assembly next week.

ai_summary: The United Kingdom is expected to recognize a Palestinian state later Sunday.
This move comes despite opposition from the United States.
Other countries may follow suit at the UN General Assembly next week.
France and Portugal are also considering recognizing Palestinian statehood.
The announcement is expected from Prime Minister Keir Starmer.

items.title: Cyberattack bring chaos to airports: Who is behind this outage?
items.standfirst: Major international airports across Europe, including London’s Heathrow and Berlin’s Brandenburg, are still experiencing operational disruptions after a suspected cyberattack hit their check-in systems, leading to cancellations and delays for thousands of passengers. Anita Mendiratta, strategic advisor in tourism and aviation, provides further insight.

items.title: Heathrow flights delayed and cancelled as cyber-attack hits European airports
items.standfirst: Attack raises questions over security as Brussels and Berlin airports’ check-in and boarding systems also affectedFlights have been delayed and cancelled at three leading European airports – including London’s largest, Heathrow – after the company behind the software used for check-in and boarding said it was hit by a cyber-attack.Airports in Brussels and Berlin are also experiencing delays and disruption as a result of the problem affecting Collins Aerospace, which works for several airlines at airports across the world. Continue reading...

items.title: Poland scrambles aircraft as Russia attacks Ukraine with hundreds of drones and missiles – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closed, you can read more on the war in Ukraine hereAt least 10 flights were cancelled out of Brussels airport and another 17 delayed by over an hour after the system was hit by a “cyber-attack” overnight on Friday, the airport said.EasyJet, among Europe’s biggest airlines, said it was currently operating as normal and did not expect the problem to impact its flights for the rest of the day, Reuters reports.Information on the situation is being continuously gathered, and Polish authorities are in contact with authorities in other countries. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A cyberattack targeted check-in systems at several European airports.

The attack caused flight delays and cancellations for many passengers.
The cyberattack targeted check-in software from Collins Aerospace.
Disruption continued for a second day at some airports.

items.title: Donald Trump Is Saying There’s a TikTok Deal. China Isn’t

items.content: A man has been killed and several other people injured in a shooting at a US country club hosting a wedding, police in New Hampshire have said.

clusters.title: BBC's Steve Rosenberg attends 'Russia's answer to Eurovision'
clusters.neutral_headline: Russia Revives Soviet-Era Song Contest After Eurovision Ban

items.title: BBC's Steve Rosenberg attends 'Russia's answer to Eurovision'
items.standfirst: Vietnam was among 23 countries competing in a glitzy Russian song contest, revived three years after Russia was banned from Eurovision.
items.content: Vietnam was among 23 countries competing in a glitzy Russian song contest, revived three years after Russia was banned from Eurovision.

items.title: Vietnam wins Russia's 'Intervision' song contest, US contestant drops out
items.standfirst: With artists from more than 20 countries, Russia on Saturday revived its Intervision song contest, which the Kremlin promotes as an alternative to Eurovision and a means to highlight "traditional values". Vietnamese singer Duc Phuc won the event with a song inspired by a poem about bamboo.
items.content: With artists from more than 20 countries, Russia on Saturday revived its Intervision song contest, which the Kremlin promotes as an alternative to Eurovision and a means to highlight "traditional values". Vietnamese singer Duc Phuc won the event with a song inspired by a poem about bamboo.

items.title: Russia revives Soviet-era song contest after being banned from Eurovision
items.standfirst: After it was barred from the Eurovision Song Contest Russia is reviving a Soviet-era version of the camp competition.
items.content: After it was barred from the Eurovision Song Contest Russia is reviving a Soviet-era version of the camp competition.

items.title: Less camp, more conservative - welcome to Russia's alternative Eurovision
items.standfirst: Banned from Eurovision after its invasion of Ukraine, Russia will hold a rival international song contest on Saturday, with an emphasis on "traditional values".
items.content: Banned from Eurovision after its invasion of Ukraine, Russia will hold a rival international song contest on Saturday, with an emphasis on "traditional values".

items.title: Russia's answer to Eurovision is less kitsch, more Kremlin

items.content: Putin resurrects a Soviet-era global song contest, to distract from Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

ai_summary: Russia revived the Intervision song contest after being banned from Eurovision.
The contest is seen as an alternative to Eurovision.
Vietnam won the contest with a song about bamboo.
The contest emphasized "traditional values".
The event was held with artists from over 20 countries.

clusters.title: Charlie Kirk memorial service to honor the conservative activist today
clusters.neutral_headline: Memorial Service Held for Conservative Activist Charlie Kirk

items.title: Charlie Kirk memorial service to honor the conservative activist today
items.standfirst: A memorial service for conservative activist Charlie Kirk is set to feature President Trump, Vice President JD Vance, Erika Kirk and others on Sunday at State Farm Stadium in Arizona.
items.content: A memorial service for conservative activist Charlie Kirk is set to feature President Trump, Vice President JD Vance, Erika Kirk and others on Sunday at State Farm Stadium in Arizona.

items.title: Trump to lead tributes at memorial for US conservative activist Charlie Kirk
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump and other top administration officials will lead tributes to the assassinated right-wing Christian activist Charlie Kirk on Sunday at a gathering in Arizona. Kirk’s killing on September 10 has further deepened political divisions in the United States.
items.content: US President Donald Trump and other top administration officials will lead tributes to the assassinated right-wing Christian activist Charlie Kirk on Sunday at a gathering in Arizona. Kirk’s killing on September 10 has further deepened political divisions in the United States.

items.title: Thousands gather at Charlie Kirk memorial in Arizona where Trump to pay tribute to slain organizer
items.standfirst: US Secret Service leads massive security presence, while conservatives demand punishment of those who disparaged rightwing ‘youth whisperer’Thousands were gathering in Arizona on Sunday for a public memorial honoring Charlie Kirk, the rightwing youth organizer who was fatally shot during an event at a Utah college.Donald Trump, his vice-president, JD Vance, and Kirk’s widow, Erika Kirk, were among a long list of prominent officials and figures expected to pay tribute to the slain activist, a reflection of his deep imprint on the president’s Make America Great Again (Maga) movement. Continue reading...
items.content: US Secret Service leads massive security presence, while conservatives demand punishment of those who disparaged rightwing ‘youth whisperer’Thousands were gathering in Arizona on Sunday for a public memorial honoring Charlie Kirk, the rightwing youth organizer who was fatally shot during an event at a Utah college.Donald Trump, his vice-president, JD Vance, and Kirk’s widow, Erika Kirk, were among a long list of prominent officials and figures expected to pay tribute to the slain activist, a reflection of his deep imprint on the president’s Make America Great Again (Maga) movement. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A memorial service honored conservative activist Charlie Kirk.
President Trump and other officials attended the service.
The service was held at State Farm Stadium in Arizona.
Kirk was fatally shot during an event in Utah.
The event reflected Kirk's influence on the MAGA movement.

items.content: President Marcos said in July there were anomalies in 9,855 flood-control projects worth more than $9.5 bn.

ai_summary: Thousands protested in Manila against corruption.
Some demonstrators clashed with police.
President Marcos acknowledged anomalies in flood-control projects.
The projects were worth over $9.5 billion.
Protests were fueled by anger over flood graft.

clusters.title: British couple held by Taliban arrive in UK after release
clusters.neutral_headline: British Couple Detained by Taliban Return to UK

items.title: British couple held by Taliban arrive in UK after release
items.standfirst: Their son tells the BBC he is "overwhelmed" by release after nearly eight months in prison.
items.content: Their son tells the BBC he is "overwhelmed" by release after nearly eight months in prison.

items.title: 'Delighted to be free': Elderly British couple who were detained by Taliban arrive in UK
items.standfirst: An elderly British couple who have arrived back in the UK after being detained in a maximum security Taliban prison are "delighted to be free", their son has told Sky News.
items.content: An elderly British couple who have arrived back in the UK after being detained in a maximum security Taliban prison are "delighted to be free", their son has told Sky News.

items.title: British couple detained by Taliban in Afghanistan return to UK
items.standfirst: Barbie Reynolds, 76, and husband Peter, 80, were released after being held without charge for nearly eight monthsA British couple who were detained without charge for nearly eight months by the Taliban in Afghanistan have arrived in the UK.Barbie Reynolds, 76, and her husband Peter, 80, were released on Friday, having been arrested as they travelled to their home in Bamyan province, central Afghanistan, in February. Continue reading...
items.content: Barbie Reynolds, 76, and husband Peter, 80, were released after being held without charge for nearly eight monthsA British couple who were detained without charge for nearly eight months by the Taliban in Afghanistan have arrived in the UK.Barbie Reynolds, 76, and her husband Peter, 80, were released on Friday, having been arrested as they travelled to their home in Bamyan province, central Afghanistan, in February. Continue reading...

items.title: Family tell of ‘immense joy’ at release of British couple detained in Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Peter and Barbie Reynolds were arrested and held without charge for eight months, raising fears for their healthA British couple have been freed from months of detention in Afghanistan, to the “immense joy” of their family.The Taliban released Barbie Reynolds, 76, and her husband, Peter, 80, after being held for eight months. Continue reading...
items.content: Peter and Barbie Reynolds were arrested and held without charge for eight months, raising fears for their healthA British couple have been freed from months of detention in Afghanistan, to the “immense joy” of their family.The Taliban released Barbie Reynolds, 76, and her husband, Peter, 80, after being held for eight months. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A British couple detained by the Taliban arrived back in the UK.
They were held without charge for nearly eight months.
The couple, Barbie and Peter Reynolds, were released.
Their family expressed "immense joy" at their release.
They were arrested while traveling to their home in Afghanistan.

clusters.title: California bans face coverings for most law enforcement officers during operations
clusters.neutral_headline: California Bans Face Coverings for Law Enforcement

items.title: California bans face coverings for most law enforcement officers during operations
items.standfirst: The ban is a direct response to recent immigration raids in Los Angeles, where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted days of protest and led President Donald Trump to deploy National Guard troops and Marines to the area.
items.content: The ban is a direct response to recent immigration raids in Los Angeles, where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted days of protest and led President Donald Trump to deploy National Guard troops and Marines to the area.

items.title: California bans masks meant to hide law enforcement officers' identities
items.standfirst: The law, opposed by police organizations, was aimed by lawmakers at immigration agents and will test state powers over the conduct of federal officials.
items.content: The law, opposed by police organizations, was aimed by lawmakers at immigration agents and will test state powers over the conduct of federal officials.(Image credit: Gregory Bull)

items.title: California becomes first state to ban face coverings for most law enforcement
items.standfirst: Local and federal agents, including immigration officials, may not wear masks while conducting official businessCalifornia will be the first state to ban most law enforcement, including federal immigration agents, from covering their faces while conducting official business under a bill signed by the state’s governor, Gavin Newsom, on Saturday.The ban is California’s direct response to a recent series of immigration raids in Los Angeles where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted protests and led Donald Trump to deploy national guard troops and marines to the city. Continue reading...
items.content: Local and federal agents, including immigration officials, may not wear masks while conducting official businessCalifornia will be the first state to ban most law enforcement, including federal immigration agents, from covering their faces while conducting official business under a bill signed by the state’s governor, Gavin Newsom, on Saturday.The ban is California’s direct response to a recent series of immigration raids in Los Angeles where federal agents wore masks while making mass arrests. The raids prompted protests and led Donald Trump to deploy national guard troops and marines to the city. Continue reading...

The law will test state powers over federal officials.

items.standfirst: Stapleton was a fixture of British TV since the 1980s and presented Newsnight, Watchdog and GMTV’s News HourThe broadcaster John Stapleton, a fixture of British television since the 1980s, has died at the age of 79 after being diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease in 2024.Stapleton’s agent, Jackie Gill, said on Sunday: “John had Parkinson’s disease, which was complicated by pneumonia. His son Nick and daughter-in-law Lisa have been constantly at his side and John died peacefully in hospital this morning.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: Israel attack on Yemeni newspaper was second deadliest on journalists ever recorded
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli killing of Yemeni journalists is deadliest attack on press in 16 years, watchdog says

items.title: Israel attack on Yemeni newspaper was second deadliest on journalists ever recorded
items.standfirst: Press freedom group says ‘brutal and unjustified attack’ is deadliest since 2009 Maguindanao massacre in PhilippinesThirty one journalists and media staff were killed by Israeli strikes on newspaper offices in Yemen last week in what the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) said on Friday was the deadliest attack on journalists in the last 16 years.Israel struck a newspaper complex in Sana’a, Yemen’s capital, which housed three Houthi-connected media outlets on 10 September. At the time, members of the Yemeni army’s press arm were finishing the weekly print edition, according to the publication’s editor-in-chief, which increased the number of journalists present during the strike. Continue reading...
items.content: Press freedom group says ‘brutal and unjustified attack’ is deadliest since 2009 Maguindanao massacre in PhilippinesThirty one journalists and media staff were killed by Israeli strikes on newspaper offices in Yemen last week in what the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) said on Friday was the deadliest attack on journalists in the last 16 years.Israel struck a newspaper complex in Sana’a, Yemen’s capital, which housed three Houthi-connected media outlets on 10 September. At the time, members of the Yemeni army’s press arm were finishing the weekly print edition, according to the publication’s editor-in-chief, which increased the number of journalists present during the strike. Continue reading...

items.title: Israeli killing of Yemeni journalists is deadliest attack on press in 16 years, watchdog says
items.standfirst: The Israeli airstrikes that killed 31 journalists and media support workers in Yemen earlier this month were the second-deadliest attack ever on the press, according to a report by the Committee to Protect Journalists, a global watchdog
items.content: The Israeli airstrikes that killed 31 journalists and media support workers in Yemen earlier this month were the second-deadliest attack ever on the press, according to a report by the Committee to Protect Journalists, a global watchdog

ai_summary: Israeli airstrikes killed 31 journalists and media support workers in Yemen.
The attack was the second-deadliest attack ever on the press.
The attack was the deadliest since the 2009 Maguindanao massacre.
The attack occurred at a newspaper complex in Sana'a, Yemen.
The Committee to Protect Journalists issued a report on the attack.
